resources.string: Visit Hyderabad
Sindh Museum
This museum is home to a vast collection of archaeological artifacts, including Gandhara sculptures, Indus Valley seals, and Islamic art.
Tombs of Talpur Mirs
Also known as "Meeran Ja Qubba". These tombs are the resting place of the Talpur rulers of Hyderabad, and are a fine example of Sindhi architecture.
Mukhi House
This is a beautifully restored 19th-century mansion, which is now a museum of Sindhi culture.
Kotri Barrage
This barrage is a major irrigation project on the Indus River, and is a popular spot for fishing and boating.
Badshahi Bungalow
The Badshahi Bungalow is the Palace of Prince Mir Hassan Ali Khan Talpur, the son of the last ruler of Hyderabad Mir Naseer Khan Talpur.
Rani Bagh
This is a beautiful garden, which is a popular spot for picnics and relaxation.
Pakka Qilla
This fort was built by the Kalhora rulers in the 18th century, and is now a popular tourist attraction.
Sheedi Monument

General Hosh Muhammad Sheedi Qambrani was an Askari unit, and also supreme commander of Talpur army. He fought against the British forces under Sir Charles James Napier at the Battle of Hyderabad, and was killed during battle on 24 March 1843.
Navalrai Clock Tower
This clock tower was built in the 19th century, and is a popular landmark in Hyderabad.
Qadam Gah Maula Ali
This is a shrine dedicated to the Prophet Muhammad\'s cousin, Ali. The Qadam Gah has been a bastion of peace even when Hyderabad was reeling from ethnic riots.
Kotri Bridge
This bridge is located on the Indus River, and is a major transportation link between Hyderabad and Karachi.
Hyderabad Gymkhana
This is a social club, which was founded in the 1870s.
Hasrat Mohani Library
The library was built in 1905 as Homestead Hall in the honor of Dr. Homestead, a well-known surgeon of Hyderabad. It is the oldest library in the city of Hyderabad.
Niaz Stadium

The Niaz Stadium is a cricket ground. The ground has a capacity of 15,000, and hosted its first test match in 1973. It was established in November 1961 by then Commissioner of Hyderabad, Niaz Ahmed. Pakistan has never lost any match, whether a test or one-day, at this ground.
Ganjo Takkar
It is a small limestone range in Hyderabad District, that runs nearly due south parallel to the Indus for about 14 miles.
Auto Bhan Road

Auto Bhan Road is a major road in Hyderabad. It is located in the Latifabad area of the city. The road is named after the late Ghulam Mustafa Khan Auto Bhan, who was a politician and philanthropist. \nIt is a busy road with a lot of traffic. It is lined with shops, restaurants, and other businesses. The road is also home to a number of educational institutions
Tomb of Mian Ghulam Shah Kalhoro
The tomb of Mian Ghulam Shah Kalhora, the founder of Hyderabad, is one of the most important monuments of the city and represents the typical architecture of Kalhoraâ€™s period.
Shahi Bazaar
It is one of the longest bazaar in Asia. The market begins from Pakka Qilla and concludes at Market Tower.
Eid Gah Hyderabad
It is a large open space that is used for Eid prayers and other religious gatherings. It is also a popular spot for picnics and relaxation.
University of Sindh Old Campus

Also known as Elsa Kazi Campus. It was founded in 1947 and is the oldest university in Sindh. The campus is spread over 120 acres and houses a number of academic buildings, residential halls, and sports facilities.
Boulevard Mall
This is the largest shopping mall in Hyderabad, with a variety of stores, restaurants, and entertainment options.
Dubbo War Memorial

The Battle of Dubbo was fought on 24 March 1843 between the forces of British East India company and the Talpur Emirs of Sindh near Hyderabad. The battle ground of Dubbo, for the first time earmarked by the Britishers. They erected a monumental stone bearing the details of the casualties. Besides the monument lies graveyard of Talpur martyrs.
See more or less information about a place.
